awd_titl_txt: GOALI: Enabling Ultra-Low Viscosity Lubricants Through Fundamental Understanding of Additive Interactions and Tribofilm Growth Mechanisms: An In-Situ Study
awd_abstract_narration:
Automobile engine oils typically include several different performance additives, each of which serves a crucial role in improving fuel efficiency and engine reliability. One of the additive types that are routinely added to such lubricants are anti-wear additives, which are required to reduce wear and failure when metal-on-metal contact occurs between the various parts within automobile engines. One such additive, a molecule based on a combination of zinc, sulfur, phosphorous, oxygen, and hydrocarbons, is so effective at reducing wear while being inexpensive to produce that it is used in nearly every automotive engine oil. This molecule works by forming surface films at certain contact points within the engine. These films serve as a protective cushion for the underlying metal parts, protecting them from wear. Despite its widespread use, it remains unclear how this molecule generates these protective films. Increasingly, automotive lubricants are being formulated with lower viscosities which help improve fuel economy and reduce undesirable emissions. Unfortunately, the molecules used to formulate these lower viscosity oils can interfere with the anti-wear molecule?s ability to generate protective films and provide adequate wear protection. This Grant Opportunities for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) research aims to contribute to solving this problem by using novel nanotechnology methods to improve our understanding of how the anti-wear protective films are formed and how their formation is affected by interactions with other types of additives. Findings of this research will inform the design of next-generation automotive lubricants and will thus have a direct impact on the U.S. economy through improved energy saving, reductions in maintenance-related costs, and reduction of undesirable emissions.

In this research, a quantitative kinetic and thermodynamic understanding of anti-wear tribofilm formation mechanisms will be formulated using novel in-situ atomic force microscopy methods, recently developed at UPenn. In-situ atomic force microscopy enables the direct probe of nanoscale mechanochemistry of zinc dialkyldithiophosphate additives (known as ZDDP-based additives) which drives formation of tribofilms, as well as their interactions with novel basestock and co-additives including molybdenum-based friction modifiers and dispersants. Synergism or antagonism between anti-wear additives and co-additive chemistries will be identified and understood through measurement and interpretation of tribofilm growth kinetics. Together with ex-situ chemical and structural characterization techniques at UPenn, as well as lubricant expertise and component-scale testing at ExxonMobil, this research will help enable predictive design, development, and implementation of advanced formulations for next-generation lubricants. By identifying how co-additives affect the fundamental mechanisms of tribofilm growth, this research will in the longer-term help identify sulfur and phosphorous-free anti-wear additives. Sulfur and phosphorous are known to have deleterious impacts on automotive emissions, and thus developing alternatives to ZDDP additives is crucial for further reducing automotive emissions.

por.por_cntn:
All practical engine oils for vehicles include multiple performance additives, which each serve crucial roles in improving fuel efficiency and engine reliability. One such additive class which is always added to these lubricants are anti-wear additives. These are needed to reduce wear and failure when metal-on-metal contact occurs between the various parts within the engine. One specific anti-wear additive, a molecule based on a combination of zinc, sulfur, phosphorous, oxygen, and hydrocarbons, is so effective at reducing wear while being inexpensive to produce that it has been used in nearly every automotive engine oil for decades, as well as certain other industrial lubricants. This molecule works by forming films that coat the steel surfaces at points of sliding contact within the engine. These films act as a protective cushion for the metal parts, protecting them from wear. Despite its widespread use, it has been unclear how this molecule generates these protective films. This is more important than ever because automotive lubricants are increasingly being formulated with lower viscosities. This helps improve fuel economy and thus reduce undesirable emissions. However, the anti-wear molecules have drawbacks: they can contribute to environmental emissions by reducing the efficiency of the catalytic converter; they do not work well enough for the lower viscosity oils where there are more extreme contact conditions; they do not function as well if steel is replaced with other lightweight materials; and they may not be sufficient for wear-protection in next-generation electric vehicle motors and drivetrains.

 

The intellectual merit of this work, which involved direct collaboration between the University of Pennsylvania and ExxonMobil, was to address these problems by using novel nanotechnology methods to improve our understanding of how the anti-wear protective films are formed in the first place.  In particular, we improved a method for studying the growth of these films in real time. In doing so, we found that the films grew in two stages, with a slower early growth phase followed by a faster rapid growth phase. After that, we discovered the films could degrade, potentially due to depletion of the molecules from the oil being tested. We also determined important physical properties of the growth of these films, namely the energy required to cause the films to grow, and how strongly that energy depends on the forces we are applying in the contact.

 

The broader impact of this research is that it can help inform the design of next-generation automotive lubricants and will thus have a direct impact on the U.S. economy through improved energy saving, reductions in maintenance-related costs, and reduction of undesirable emissions. This includes guiding longer-term research to identify sulfur- and phosphorous-free anti-wear additives for future lubricants with reduced emissions; developing anti-wear additives that work even better under the harsher conditions present when low viscosity oils are used; and developing anti-wear additives for engines made of lightweight materials, or for electric vehicle motors. The work also led to two internships conducted at ExxonMobil by the PhD student, providing her with hands-on industry experience. As well, knowledge developed in this project was included in an advanced course for upper-level undergraduate students and graduate students that focuses on the nanoscale origins of friction and wear. Finally, the PhD student and the Principal Investigator overseeing the project participated in public outreach events to educate the public on the importance of friction and wear in everyday life and in technology, and the excitement of scientific research in this area.
